active_learning.discussion_prompt: Why are prime moduli essential in asymmetric cryptography like Diffie-Hellman or DSA? Compare the security implications of using a prime versus a composite modulus, citing real-world examples from NIST standards (e.g., subgroup confinement attacks in DH with composite moduli) and historical failures like the ROCA vulnerability.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Cryptography. Generate high-quality Anki-compatible flashcards for the topic 'Prime Modulus Requirements' (Topic Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Cryptography > Asymmetric Cryptography > Mathematical Foundations > Finite Field Cryptography (FFC) > Prime Modulus Requirements). Use the provided research context, learning objectives, active learning elements, and 4-layer scaffolding to ensure pedagogical depth. **Research Context Summary:** Prime modulus is a large prime p for modular arithmetic in RSA/DH/DSA, ensuring finite field GF(p) security. NIST SP 800-57 Pt1 Rev5: Key mgmt, 2048+ bit primes for DH/DSA. FIPS 186-5: DSA primes. SP 800-56A: Safe primes (p=2q+1) vs strong primes. SP 800-133: Implementation. Generation: Miller-Rabin. Vulnerabilities: Composites enable Pollard's rho. Sources: https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-57pt1r5.pdf, https://doi.org/10.6028/NIST.FIPS.186-5, https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-56Ar3.pdf. **Incorporate:** - Learning objectives (span Bloom's: REMEMBER to CREATE). - Scaffolding: Layer 1 (foundations), Layer 2 (components), etc. - Active learning: Draw from discussion/activities for scenario-based cards. - Connect to entry: Finite Fields. **Output Format (JSON array of flashcards):** Each flashcard: {"type": "Q&A" or "MCQ", "front": "...", "back": "...", "explanation": "...", "bloom_level": "REMEMBER", "layer": "1", "source": "NIST SP 800-57"}. Follow flashcard_schema strictly for distractors. Generate 25 diverse cards covering all objectives/layers.
